Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story: Tonight, my phone buzzes with a message from my sister: “Don’t forget, dinner at 7. Mom’s making your favorite.” I know how much these family dinners mean, especially since Dad’s been working late and we rarely all sit together anymore. As the oldest brother, I’m expected to be there, to set an example, to keep the peace when my younger siblings bicker. But as I glance at the clock, I remember tonight is also the regular Thursday service at synagogue. I’ve always tried to be consistent, to show up even when it’s not a holiday, because it matters to me—and to the community. Still, I know the minyan will be fine without me; there are always enough people. My mind races between the warmth of my family’s table and the quiet comfort of the sanctuary. I feel pulled in two directions, guilty at the thought of letting anyone down. I wish I could be in both places at once, but I know I have to choose.
